data.description: Interdisciplinary study of Sami (Lapp) people of Scandinavia past and present. Indigenous modes of expression and worldview, contemporary cultural and political activism. Extensive discussion of connections to Native American and Inuit experiences; rise of U.S. and other indigenous peoples' movements.
data.title: SAMI CULTURE, YESTERDAY AND TODAY

data.description: A look at the Kalevala, the Finnish creation myth and national epic of Finland, and how it affected Finnish national identity and the eventual Finnish independence from Russia.
data.title: IN TRANSLATION: KALEVALA AND FINNISH FOLK-LORE

data.description: Addresses different aspects of community life and culture in the Upper Midwest; topics include ethnic groups, religious life, cultural landscapes, oral narrative, music, and material culture.
data.title: LOCAL CULTURE AND IDENTITY IN THE UPPER MIDWEST

data.description: Advanced directed study projects as arranged with a faculty member.
data.title: INDEPENDENT STUDY IN FOLKLORE (GRADUATE)

data.description: An Afro Asian perspective provides a lens through which intersections between Asian American and African American dance and martial arts are studied and practiced. Asian American and African American movement genres provide tools to explore dance fusion, choreography, and improvisation, to create dances informed by African American and Asian American legacies of struggle, innovation and transformation, while cognizant of historical forces of oppression and racism. Building connections through respectful communication with others are learned through dance practice, discussion and writing about concepts learned through readings, videos, and guest artist visits. Engagement with dance as a cultural vehicle for creative problem-solving and risk-taking occurs through guided class or smaller group activities.
data.title: AFRO ASIAN IMPROV: FROM HIP HOP TO MARTIAL ARTS FUSION

data.description: An introduction to the genres of American Indian Folklore. Special attention is given to creation stories, trickster tales, and the relationship between folklore and historical memory.
data.title: AMERICAN INDIAN FOLKLORE

data.description: An introduction to the study of religion through the lens of sacred places and journeys, including pilgrimage.
data.title: SACRED PLACES AND JOURNEYS

data.description: An introductory ethnomusicology course providing a variety of ways to approach musics typically not covered in music history courses. Active engagement with these musics within their larger world contexts.
data.title: INTRODUCTION TO MUSIC CULTURES OF THE WORLD

data.description: Combines a fieldwork practicum with scrutiny of the cultural, political, and ethical dimensions underlying the documentation and public presentation of folklore through festivals, exhibitions, publications, audio-visual productions, and digital archival collections.
data.title: FIELD METHODS AND THE PUBLIC PRESENTATION OF FOLKLORE

data.description: Continuation of introductory instruction in aural skills.
data.title: MUSICA PRACTICA: AURAL SKILLS 2

data.description: Continuation of strategies for composing, understanding, and writing about music.
data.title: MUSICA PRACTICA 2

data.description: Description and analysis of native cultures, and the role of environmental and historical factors in North America.
data.title: INDIANS OF NORTH AMERICA

data.description: Directed study as arranged with a faculty member.
data.title: DIRECTED STUDY IN FOLKLORE FOR UNDERGRADUATES

data.description: Examination of shared traditions and historical connections between the North and Northwest of Europe. Readings of medieval and pre-modern Scandinavian, Scottish, Welsh and Irish sagas, histories, talkes. Discussion of the role of folklore in modern Celtic and Scandinavian societies.
data.title: CELTIC-SCANDINAVIAN CULTURAL INTERRELATIONS

data.description: Examines and interprets the roles of American Indian women in traditional societies, and in contemporary North America.
data.title: AMERICAN INDIAN WOMEN

data.description: Examines the relationship between dominant images of gender representation as they emerge in expressive culture in various societies.
data.title: GENDER AND EXPRESSIVE CULTURE

data.description: Examines the verbal, musical, customary, and material folklore of Scandinavian Americans, with emphasis on the upper Midwest.
data.title: SCANDINAVIAN AMERICAN FOLKLORE

data.description: Exploration of various topics in the study of folklore, folklife, myth, foodways, or music.
data.title: ELEMENTARY TOPICS IN FOLKLORE

data.description: Exploration of various topics in the study of folklore, folklife, myth, foodways, or music.
data.title: INTERMEDIATE TOPICS IN FOLKLORE

data.description: Exploration of various topics in the study of folklore, folklife, myth, foodways, or music.
data.title: ADVANCED TOPICS IN FOLKLORE

data.description: Explore everyday communication in social media. Learn digital recording technologies for documenting everyday communication and the use of digital content in social media.
data.title: DIGITAL STORYTELLING FOR SOCIAL MEDIA

data.description: Explore horror as cultural phenomenon and how it represents various forms of cultural/national angst.
data.title: HORROR AS EXPRESSIONS OF NATIONAL ANGST

data.description: Explores artistic, social, sensory, and spiritual expressions through food that convey personal, group, and place-based identities, ethnicity, gender, and class in work and play. Reviews range of food writing and scholarly perspectives including culinary historical, structural-functional, and performance.
data.title: FOODWAYS

data.description: Explores evidence of belief in the supernatural in the modern world as it appears in the context of folk religion, folk medicine, legends, folk drama, ritual and custom, and media accounts and presentations. Surveys scholarly approaches to the topic. Course not available to students with credits for Folklore 415 before Fall 2023.
data.title: THE SUPERNATURAL IN THE MODERN WORLD

data.description: Explores the development of the vampire legend in folklore, rumor, literature, cinema, television, and popular culture and in relation to topics such as colonization, race, gender, sexuality, and class.
data.title: VAMPIRES

data.description: Explores the performance, transmission, and consumption of traditional and popular musics outside of the standard Euro-American context. Employs musical-analytic and critical approaches to trace transnational musical circulation.
data.title: MUSICAL CULTURES OF THE WORLD

data.description: Exploring the oral nature and performance traditions of folklore, ethnography, tales and ballads, literature and culture from Nordic areas and Scandinavia.
data.title: THE NORDIC STORYTELLER

data.description: Focuses on language and its culture, example topics include: extinction and revival, language and nationhood, how widely and deeply languages differ, language and worldview, writing systems and literacy, language discrimination and inequality.
data.title: GLOBAL LANGUAGE ISSUES

data.description: Focuses on the tools (material, methodological, and ethical) for doing ethnographic fieldwork in musical contexts.
data.title: ETHNOGRAPHIC METHODS FOR MUSIC AND SOUND

data.description: Folklore of Central, Eastern and Northern Europe and among emigrants from these regions in North America. A survey of genres of folklore, history of research, and modes of interpretation, past and present.
data.title: FOLKLORE OF CENTRAL, EASTERN AND NORTHERN EUROPE

data.description: Folklore of ethnic, regional, religious, and occupational cultures, emphasizing how diverse peoples (African Americans, American Indians, Appalachians, Chicanos, Germans, Irish, Jews, Mormons, miners, service workers, etc.) use traditional festivals, artifacts, songs and stories to express their experiences within American life.
data.title: INTRODUCTION TO AMERICAN FOLKLORE

data.description: Intoductory istruction in aural skills.
data.title: MUSICA PRACTICA: AURAL SKILLS 1

data.description: Introduction to Javanese theatre performance in a Javanese epic tradition. Includes use of Javanese gamelan music as accompaniment for dance drama.
data.title: JAVANESE PERFORMANCE REPERTORY

data.description: Introduction to comparative ethnic studies, examining race, ethnicity, and indigeneity within the United States. Includes perspectives from African American, American Indian, Asian American, and Chican@ and Latin@ studies.
data.title: INTRODUCTION TO COMPARATIVE US ETHNIC AND AMERICAN INDIAN STUDIES

data.description: Introduction to development of music in the European tradition, 1750 to the present.
data.title: SURVEY OF THE HISTORY OF WESTERN MUSIC

data.description: Introduction to ethnomusicology, including historical survey of major works in the field, classification of musical instruments, measurement of tuning systems and concepts of scale, mode and rhythm in non-Western music.
data.title: PROSEMINAR IN ETHNOMUSICOLOGY

data.description: Introduction to folk cultural groups and folklore forms of Wisconsin.
data.title: FOLKLORE OF WISCONSIN

data.description: Mythology, literature, ritual, traditions, medieval folklore, and religion from Nordic areas and Scandinavia.
data.title: NORDIC MYTHOLOGY

data.description: Oral nature, structure, performance traditions, and epic ideology, from various world areas.
data.title: FOLK EPICS

data.description: Oral traditional literature of Eastern Europe: ritual and lyric poetry, epic, and folktale.
data.title: SLAVIC AND EAST EUROPEAN FOLKLORE

data.description: Representation and self-representation of ethnic cultures in Wisconsin. For example: museums, mass media, ethnic theater.
data.title: ETHNIC REPRESENTATIONS IN WISCONSIN

data.description: Strategies for composing, understanding, and writing about music.
data.title: MUSICA PRACTICA 1

data.description: Survey of Irish folklore and folklife, including narrative, music, dance, customs, material culture, and foodways, in both Ireland and beyond.
data.title: THE IRISH TRADITION

data.description: Survey of shamanism as a religious tradition and sociocultural force in Siberian, Asian, and Native American societies. Exploration of shamanic rituals, roles, cosmology. Cultural and political uses of shamanism in traditional and modern contexts.
data.title: SHAMANISM

data.description: Surveys folklore in the United States and around the world, with a comparative emphasis on ways in which individuals and groups use beliefs, songs, stories, sayings, dances, festivals, and artifacts to address issues of identity, authenticity, and authority, in complex societies.
data.title: INTRODUCTION TO FOLKLORE

data.description: Technique and practice of classical Javanese dance in its musical, historical and cultural contexts.
data.title: JAVANESE PERFORMANCE

data.description: The Icelandic sagas viewed in their social, cultural, and literary contexts. An introduction to one of the greatest bodies of vernacular literature of the early Middle Ages.
data.title: THE WORLD OF SAGAS

data.description: The oral tradition and the written word; the composition of stories, relationship between performer and audience, and transmission of tradition in various African societies.
data.title: THE AFRICAN STORYTELLER

data.description: The relationship between myth and tale, history, culture. Myth research; methodological approaches; world mythologies; myth and modern times.
data.title: MYTH

data.description: Topics in Folklore in various cultures and time periods.
data.title: TOPICS IN FOLKLORE

data.description: Topics in ethnomusicology within a cross-cultural framework; melodic typology, scale and tuning systems, mode, rhythm, ornamentation, improvisation techniques, oral and written traditions of composition, notation systems, and function of music society.
data.title: SEMINAR IN ETHNOMUSICOLOGY

data.description: Topics in historical or contemporary folklore and folklife pertaining to persistently marginalized racial or ethnic groups in the United States.
data.title: TOPICS IN AMERICAN FOLKLORE: ETHNIC STUDIES

data.description: Types of heroes, social functions, and tellers; tales from four cultures.
data.title: THE FOLK TALE

data.description: Work as an intern with a public agency or a private non-profit organization involved in public folklore projects.
data.title: PRACTICUM IN PUBLIC FOLKLORE
